guide.title: Gentoo Infrastructure -- Setting up new Project Pages
guide.subtitle: Main Page
guide.abstract: This page explains how to set up new pages for top level projects within the Gentoo Linux project.

chapter.title: Project Pages for the Gentoo Linux Project

body.p: This document describes how to set up new project pages for the Gentoo Linux project. It is geared towards top-level projects, but may be applicable to other projects as well. This document presupposes the following conditions:

ul.li: The user has set up a local copy of the gentoo repository.
The user is familiar with cvs in general and how Gentoo Linux uses cvs, specifically.
The user is familiar with basic XML and/or HTML syntax.
The user has emerged libxslt on their computer

body.p: Gentoo Linux uses guide-xml for its documentation format. Users will need to familiarize themselves with guide-xml syntax. Users should start with the Gentoo Linux XML Guide to learn basic syntax.

section.title: Create the new CVS directory and the default index page

body.p: Decide what your new project will be called and create the directory within your local CVS repository.
body.pre: # cd /home/cvsroot/gentoo/xml/htdocs/proj/en/ replace /home/cvsroot with your local CVS root path # mkdir <name of your directory> # cvs add <name of your directory> # cd <name of your directory> # vim index.xml create your document using guide-xml syntax and save it
body.impo: It is critical that you always run your documents through xmllint before committing to cvs.

pre.caption: Using xmllint to validate your document

body.pre: # xmllint index.xml fix any syntactical errors that xmllint identifies
body.p: Next, we commit the document to CVS.
body.pre: # cvs add index.xml # cvs commit -m "your commit message here" index.xml
body.p: At this point, your document has been committed to CVS. It will show up on the web site at :20 past the hour during the scheduled update.
